question: Question_B_06_(b)
statement:
Consider the triangle \emph{T} in three dimensions with vertices
\emph{(0, 1, 2)}, \emph{(1, 1, 5)} and \emph{(â1, 2, 2)}.

Consider also the plane \emph{P} that contains \emph{T}.

What is the normal (perpendicular) direction to \emph{P}?
sols:
First pick any two linearly independent vectors lying in \emph{P}
(meaning the heads and tails of the vectors can be drawn in the plane
\emph{P}). A convenient choice will be two sides of the triangle
\emph{T}: \emph{(1, 1, 5) - (0, 1, 2) = (1, 0, 3)} and \emph{(-1, 2, 2)
- (0, 1, 2) = (-1, 1, 0)}.

A normal vector to the plane is given by the cross product of these two
vectors (which is calculated in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2010/Question B6 (a)}{part
(a)} already):

\begin{align*}\vec{N} = (1,0,3) \times (-1,1,0) = (-3,-3,1)\end{align*}

The above vector gives the normal direction.
hints: How does the cross product relate to perpendicular vectors?
